column12: R.|Journal of Geophysical Research (Planets)|126|5|e06845|Hydroxylation by solar wind protons has been simulated in our laboratory on Apollo 17 lunar sample 78421
column13: a very mature regolith sample that is rich with agglutinates (68%). The goal of this study was to determine the rate of hydroxyl formation and their thermal stability by monitoring changes in the SiOH (hydroxyl) stretching band near 3 μm using diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). A 2 keV H<SUB>2</SUB><SUP>+</SUP> ion beam was used to simulate proton implantation on 78421 and on a crushed fused silica sample. We find that the OH band does not change unless the samples have been annealed in vacuum prior to irradiation. Qualitatively
column14: the OH bands for the fused silica and 78421 are very different. The OH band for fused silica is centered at 2.74 μm and is relatively sharp ranging from 2.67 to 3.1 μm at full width at half maximum (FWHM)
column15: while the OH band for 78421 is centered at 3.0 μm and ranges from 2.74 to 3.37 μm at FWHM. The increase in wavelength and broadened nature of the OH band in 78421 may be associated with the OH's proximity to surface defects and/or lattice vacancies. The lack of the H<SUB>2</SUB>O bending mode at 6.1 μm indicates that any adsorbed terrestrial H<SUB>2</SUB>O is below our detection limit
column16: and therefore the H<SUB>2</SUB>O stretching mode at 2.9 μm is not significantly contributing to the broad 3 μm OH band and implies that proton implantation by itself does not lead to water formation. To simulate the maximum dayside temperature on the lunar surface
column17: the lunar sample was heated after proton irradiation. The proton induced OH concentration was reduced by as much as 25% after heating to 400 K (127°C).|http://dx.doi.org/10.1029/2021JE006845
